title: Four core exercises to make you a better cyclist

Four core exercises to make you a better cyclist

We all want to get faster and ride for longer, and that means more than just hours on the bike. Being able to hold a strong position allows you to be more aerodynamic, to transfer power more efficiently and protect from aches and pains. And that comes from having solid foundations in the form of your core, the abdominal and back muscles that support the spine and connect your upper and lower body.

‘Core training helps strengthen and stabilise the muscle groups that support your legs so you can ride more comfortably for longer,’ says coach Ric Stern (cyclecoach.com). ‘Strength exercises have been shown to increase cycling performance, particularly FTP and sprint power, and core training increases the strength and mineral density of your bones, which protects against osteoporosis, an issue that affects cyclists, especially if you’ve been trying to hit or stay at a target weight.’

A strong core will also improve your functional fitness, making you more useful off the bike. There’s no point riding a bike for three hours if you can’t move afterwards.

Stern has chosen four exercises to combine into a circuit, with each working the core in different ways. But don’t try to do too much too soon.

‘If you haven’t ever squatted before, or for a long time, start with your bodyweight, then progress to a kettlebell or dumb-bells,’ he says. Note that between them these moves will also work your upper and lower back, shoulders, legs and glutes. A strong core isn’t much use on its own if the other links in the chain are weak.

Planks and tall planks

Target: Core

Sets: 1 Reps: 3× 30sec

To do a plank, start by lying down on your front. Raise onto your forearms, with your elbows directly under your shoulders, and hold your body in a straight line from head to heels. Hold for 30 seconds, rest and then repeat for three reps, aiming to build to 3× 60sec. Focus on engaging the core by pulling your belly button up and keeping your torso flat and in line.

To progress, start in the plank position, then push up one arm at a time so you’re in a press-up position. Return to the plank position, minimising movements in your core, and repeat for 30sec. Start with 3× 30sec and progress to 3× 60sec.

Why do it? ‘Planks really build a strong core, which helps you keep a good posture while cycling and helps prevent or reduce back ache, especially on a long ride,’ says Stern. ‘They can also help you avoid getting a rounded back, which you can get from too much time spent in an aero position on the bike.’

Box Superman

Target: Core, plus shoulders, hamstrings and glutes

Sets: 3 Reps: 8

Rest on your knees and hands. Keeping your back flat, engage your core by pulling your belly button upwards, then extend your left arm forwards and at the same time extend your right leg backwards so both limbs are straight.

Bring your elbow and knee in to meet beneath your abdominals. Return to the starting position and hold briefly before repeating for 8 reps. Repeat on the other side. Aim to start with 3× 8 reps on each side, and build to 4× 12 reps.

Why do it? ‘It helps to build a strong core, and strengthens your upper back and shoulders, which helps with positioning on the bike,’ says Stern. ‘It also strengthens the posterior chain – the muscles from your upper back to your calves – which can be weak in cyclists. A strong posterior chain increases power on the bike and helps activate muscles such as the glutes correctly.’

Crunch to extension

Target: Abdominals, lower back, upper back

Sets: 3 Reps: 8

Lie on the floor on your back. Hold a kettlebell, medicine ball or other light weight to your chest and bring your knees up until they are at 90° to your body. Extend your arms and legs as far away from each other as you can, bringing the weight over your head and close to the floor and keeping your feet off the ground.

Keep your core engaged and your back against the floor. Return to the starting position to complete the rep. Do 3× 8 reps and progress to a heavier weight and 3-4 sets of 12.

Why do it? ‘As well as working the core, it also helps strengthen your lower back and shoulders.’

Goblet squats

Target: Core, quadriceps, glutes, erector spinae, upper back, calves and hamstrings

Sets: 4 Reps: 12

Hold a weight such as a kettlebell in front of your chest and stand with your feet slightly wider than your shoulders. Lock and engage your core with your chest upright. Bend your knees and push your glutes backwards and drop slowly, keeping your weight on your heels. Only go as far as you are comfortable with and that allows you to maintain good form.

To return to an upright position, keep your core engaged and push up through your heels. Start with a light weight to ensure the correct movement pattern with 4× 12 reps, and as the weight goes up you should move to 5× 3-5 reps.

Why to do it? ‘Squatting is a fantastic all-round exercise. As well as building core strength for stability, squats produce more power for cycling by strengthening your legs and glutes for short sprints or longer, more sustained efforts.’
